In 2007, Jona joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Jona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used for additional capital for her business. Jona is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Jona from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand the business. 

About GDMPC

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon C. is from the village of Poblacion, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old. Corazon is married and has ten adult children. To make a living, Corazon owns and operates a business venture raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from growing and selling petchay, cabbage, eggplant, ampalaya and other vegetables. Corazon has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Corazon joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used for additional capital for her business. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fourth loan taken by Corazon from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey J., 52, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. J. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of about $1 each per day. Two of her children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of about $3 each per day. Every month the family has to spend $41 on food, $3 on their children's education and $20 on other expenses.  

J. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the family use

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom A., 47, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. A. is employed as a garment factory worker for an income of $5 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $4 per day. Every month the family has to spend $61 on food, $5 on electricity, $15 on their children's education and $5 on transportation. 

A. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow rice for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a plot of farmland to grow rice

loans.name: Sorn's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of thirteen people located in Daeum Rues village, Kandal province. Mrs. Sorn Y. is 51 years old and is the village bank president selected by the members, who will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Sorn Y. is a widow with two children, who are seamstresses in the garment factory. She farms rice on a rented plot of land and works very hard to support the family. Since she does not have enough money to support the farm, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice

loans.name: Komilahon's Group

texts.en:
Komilahon I. is the leader of this group. She is 50 years old and married. Together the couple is bringing up a son, who is a 13 year old schoolboy. In 1999, after they moved to their new house, the family decided to start their own business of livestock breeding. Since then, they have been successful enough to keep on doing it. The head of the family earns additional income by working in the sphere of amateur art activities. Out of business profits they have the possibility of building a house. Komilahon wants to get a loan in order to purchase sheep for further fattening and resale. In the future the family is planning to build a stable for animal breeding.

Saerahon T. is 31 years old and married. Temporarily, she has to raise her daughter and son alone because of her husband working in Russia. In 1998, having gathered a rich cotton harvest, they purchased cattle. Since then the family's main income comes out of cattle breeding. They currently have three cows and two sheep. Earnings have made it possible to do house repairs and to buy a kitchen set. The loan purpose is to buy fodder. In the future Saerahon’s family wants to build a new house, to obtain furniture and to increase their stock of cattle. 

Rahmatillo B. is 31 years old and married. Together with his wife, whose profession is a teacher, they are bringing up three children. The elder son goes to school and the daughter is in kindergarten. The main source of the family's budget is cattle breeding. This was started when his father presented them with a bull, and now the family has a milk cow with her calf. Out of profits they have managed to build a house. The loan purpose is to purchase sheep for further fattening. In the future Rahmatillo wants to finish up his house building, to buy a car and to build a farm for breeding animals.

Yakutai I. is 54 years old and married. She has two sons. The older son is a dentist and the younger one works in Russia. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 5,000 KGS, Yakutai started to breed livestock. She applied for the loan in order to purchase two sheep for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Tourn

texts.en:
Tourn S., 63, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. S. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of around $1 each per day. S. is also a tailor at home. Two of her children produce cement steps to sell, earning an income of about $3 each per day. Every month the family has to spend $56 on food, $5 on electricity and $6 on transportation.  

S. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase more materials for producing more cement steps to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy more materials for producing more cement steps to sell

loans.name: Shasta Daisy Group

texts.en:
Myrna C. is from the village of Sepac, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old. Myrna is the leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Shasta Daisy.

Myrna is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns and operates a retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as canned goods, noodles, milk, coffee, shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Myrna has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Myrna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Myrna is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken by Myrna from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey K., 56, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. K. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of  about $2 each per day. One of her children is a mechanic, earning an income of approximately $10 per day to help cover the family expenses. Every month the family has to spend $60 on food, $3 on electricity and $5 on transportation. 

K. is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase spare parts for her child’s business as a mechanic. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy spare parts for the machine to improve their child's business

loans.name: Glorina

texts.en:
Glorina D. is from the village of Villa Coloma, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 37 years old, married, and has six school-aged children. To make a living, she operates a motorcycle transport service. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $115 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Glorina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. 

Glorina is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to repair her existing vehicle for better service. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Sok Lim's Group

texts.en: This group loan has three members who live in Trapeang Kralanh village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sok Lim L., who was born in 1983, was selected as president of the loan by the other members who will use their portions of the loan for varied goals. Mrs. Sok Lim L. owns a general store in the local village where she sells groceries to earn a profit to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand but she does not have enough money to do so. Mrs. Sok Lim L. is applying for a loan to buy more groceries to sell. She is a widow with two children; one is a student and the youngest is seven months old.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Iv

texts.en:
Iv I., 48, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Iv is employed at a brick factory and as a farmer, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 5.3 per day. One of her children is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 1.7 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 10 on electricity, and USD 12.5 on the children’s education every month.

Iv is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work

loans.name: Mabona Twimukye Group, Ibanda

texts.en: Operating a retail shop dealing in general merchandise is a formidable business venture, but one that allows Paul K., 31, of Mabona Twimukye group, Ibanda, to earn money to fulfill his family obligations in Mabona trading centre, Ibanda. A father of six, Paul began the business with little capital, but now earns 100,000 UGX monthly; he is seeking a loan to expand his business and purchase additional stock, for which there is a ready market.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for the store

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old married father of two school-age children who started working as a home painter and gypsum board interior decorator in 1994. Due to his long experience in this field, he has built a good business reputation. He works closely with some construction entrepreneurs in charge of big projects and also, upon request, with individuals asking for his services.

Today, he is requesting a loan of $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a painting machine and additional painting supplies. He is optimist for the future and hopes that his business will continue to grow in the coming years.

loans.use: To purchase a painting machine and additional painting supplies

loans.name: Teng

texts.en:
Teng H., 52, is married and resides with his wife and five children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. H. is a motor-taxi driver and farmer, earning an income of USD 6.5 per day. His wife is also a farmer, earning an income of USD 1.5 per day. Three of his children are employed at different workplaces, earning incomes of about USD 2 each per day to help cover the family's expenses. The family has to spend USD 40 on food, USD 17 on electricity supply, and USD 25 on children’s education every month.

Teng is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a new motorbike to operate his business more efficiently. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike to operate the business more efficiently

loans.name: Gulhumor's Group

texts.en:
Gulhumor S., the group’s leader, is 41, married to an electrical inspector, and the mother of four children, all of them schoolboys. The family is engaged in cattle breeding and farming, enterprises inherited from parents. As well, Gulhumor earns her living by working as a teacher. From their earning the family has managed to make house repairs and build a kitchen. They are requesting a loan in order to purchase a calf to raise and then sell.

Gulnar J., the treasurer of the group, is a 51-year-old widow raising two children, a 15-year-old son and a 13-year-old daughter, both students. She earns her living by cattle breeding and farming, and also works as a school teacher. Out of earnings she has managed to make house repairs. Gulnar hopes to get a loan in order to purchase a cow to increase her stock, and in the future hopes to arrange her children's weddings, obtain a car, and expand her business.

Saidahon M., 41 and married to a seller, is the mother of three children, all students. The family earns money by farming, cultivating cotton, rice, corn, carrots and turnips. Earnings have allowed them to build a cow-shed and install gates. The loan will enable them to purchase land and chemical fertilizers. In the future, Saidahon is planning to build a bath-house and kitchen and make house repairs.

Alibaba K., a 24-year-old bachelor. lives with his mother, sister and brother. His mother is a pensioner already, but also works as a school teacher. Alibaba himself is an expert in resuscitation. The family has a common business, the breeding of cattle. Earnings from that enterprise have given them the opportunity to purchase a computer. In order to purchase livestock animals, the family hopes to get a loan, and in the future Alibaba is planning to purchase a house, marry and increase the cattle stock.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en: Ofelia S. is from the village of Bitnong Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 48 years old and is married with five adult children. Ofelia owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling clothing and shoe products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Ofelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. Ofelia is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 3rd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Bitnong Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao C. was born in 1969 and lives in Trapeang Kralaong village in Takeo province. She is a broom seller who is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Vuthy Noem, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family; moreover, he is a construction worker. Since Mrs. Mao C.'s business is going well, she wants to expand. She is applying for a loan to buy more brooms to sell. She is the mother of two children; one is enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is four years old. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: to buy more brooms to sell

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.ru: Курбоналиев Мухаммад житель района Джиликул. Возраст, 26 лет. Холост. Образование высшее, врач. По профессии не работает. Сейчас он занимается торговлей горючего (бензин, солярка и масло), так как этот бизнес приносит доход. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 8 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Muhammad K. is a resident of Jilikul. He is 26 years old and single. He has a degree as a medical doctor, but he does not practice medicine. He works selling fuel (gasoline, diesel, and oil) since this work brings in a livable wage. He has been doing this for eight years. He is taking out a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increasing sales

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom C., 60, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. C. and her husband grow rice and raise animals, earning an income of USD 2.50 each per day, and two of her children are employed at a factory, earning an income of about USD 3 each per day to help cover the family expenses. Every month the family has to spend USD 30 on food, USD 5 on their electricity supply, and USD 25 on their children’s education.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work

loans.name: Mahira's Group

texts.en: Mahira E. is the leader of this group. She is 23 and married. Her husband raises money by working as a private builder. Together, the couple brings up a son. Mainly, the family gets some profits out of farming. Still, in order to obtain a refrigerator, the family needs to obtain a loan. In future Mahira wants to purchase other necessary household appliances, to build a house for her brother and to pay for her son’s circumcision. Matluba E. is the treasurer of the group. She is 49 and married. Her husband makes his bread by working as a private builder. They have two daughters, one of whom is divorced and lives with her parents. The family earns money by cultivating potatoes and cotton on their own allotment and out of their business profits they have managed to make house repairs and to arrange for their daughter’s wedding. In order to make their plans to purchase fertilizer and garlic come true, the family needs to obtain a loan. In future Matluba wants to build a house and to pay for her grandson’s circumcision. Patilahon O., 66, is married and her husband is a pensioner already. The couple has a son, 35 years old, who is a private builder. The family business consists of cultivating corn and onions, and also cattle breeding. Their earnings gave them an opportunity to increase their cattle stock and to build a stable. The purpose of this loan is to buy potato and onion seeds and to fertilize their soil for planting. In future, Patilahon wants to arrange her son’s wedding, make house repairs and enlarge her stock-raising business. Talasbek D., 25, is married and has two children. The family makes its bread by having their own business selling cigarettes and sunflower seeds, which they started fourteen years ago. Today, at home, they have opened a shop where Talasbek’s wife sells. Also they have a billiard room, which gives a daily income. Besides those businesses, they are engaged in cattle breeding and Talasbek earns additional money by working as a taxi-driver. The purpose of this loan is to expand their commodity business. In future the family wants to build a bath-house and increase their cattle stock. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea S., 60, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

S. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2.50 per day and her husband buys cows to resell for an income of about USD 4 per day. Two of her children are employed, earning an income of about USD 4 each per day to help cover the family expenses. Every month the family has to spend USD 35 on food, USD 8 on their electricity supply, and USD 30 on their children’s education.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to enable her husband to purchase more cows to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy more cows to resell

loans.name: Nurila

texts.en: Nurila S. is a 48-year-old single mother of three children. She works as an accountant and is described as a benevolent, responsible and very hardworking woman. In 1993, after the breakdown of the Soviet Union and in order to support her family, Nurila began to develop her business of stock-breeding. Today, she has two milch cows, whose milk she sells to the local dairy factory, and three horses. Also, Nurila is engaged in the cultivation of kidney beans and perennial herbs, which serve as forage for her cattle. Nurila plans to use this loan of 70,000 KGS to buy twenty sheep for fattening and reselling and one cow. With her future revenues, Nurila plans to buy a mini-truck for transporting milk products to customers and consumers in different regions. About Bai-Tushum and Partners: Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable members of the population. It is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, it contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To buy twenty sheep for fattening and reselling and one cow

loans.name: Mrs. Nou Chom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Ten people who live in Thlok village in Takeo province make up this village bank group loan. Mrs. N. C., who was born in 1959, is the village bank president who was selected by the other members. They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

She and her husband, Mr. Chies Chorn, are farmers who own a half-hectare plot of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support their famiL.. Besides farming, they have a lot of free time. So, to improve this condition, Mrs. N. C. is seeking a loan to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business. 

She is a mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a bread shop, while another one is employed at a petroleum station and the others are attending school.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria M. is from Barangay Villa Coloma, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 56 years old and is married with five adult children. Gloria owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Chum P., 20, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. P.'s husband appears in the photograph because P. was not available.

P. is a hairdresser, earning an income of USD 5 per day and her husband is an electronics repairman, also earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Every month the family has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 5 on their electricity supply, and USD 10 on public transportation.

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more hairdressing supplements to operate her business more efficiently. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more supplements to improve her hairdressing business

loans.name: Morm

texts.en:
Morm T., 37, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

T. sells groceries and coffee, earning an income of USD 7.50 per day while her husband grows rice and raises cows to sell, earning an income of about USD 4 per day to help cover the family expenses. Every month the family has to spend USD 30 on food, USD 15 on public transportation, and USD 15 on their children’s education.

T. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase more groceries and coffee to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries and coffee to sell

loans.name: Oum's Group

texts.en:
Oum S., a 38-year-old married woman, is the village bank president selected by the 16 members of this village loan located in Daeum Rues village, Kandal province. Each member of this loan group will use his or her portion of the loan for a different purpose. 

Oum S. and her husband, Mr. Oem Ann, sell noodles and groceries from their home and are able to earn some profit to support the family. With both of these businesses, they hope that they can improve their family's living standards. In order to enlarge their business activities and increase their income, Oum S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries and noodles. This couple has four childR.: three are seamstresses in the garment factory and O. attends the local school.

loans.use: to buy more groceries and noodles

loans.name: Seoun

texts.en:
Seoun P., 41, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. P. appears in the photograph with her family.

P. is a garment factory worker, earning an income of USD 3.50 per day while her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 4 per day to help cover the family expenses. Every month the family has to spend USD 42 on food, USD 5 on electricity supply, and USD 30 on public transportation.

Chorn is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work

loans.name: Mrs. Srey Mom Kol Group

texts.en: This group loan has four members who live in Pongro village in Takeo province. Mrs. Srey Mom K., 24 years old, has been selected as group leader by the other members who will use their portions of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Srey Mom K. is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. She also owns a general store in the local village. Her problem is that her field's soil is infertile. To improve production, Mrs. Srey Mom K. is seeking  a loan to buy fertilizer. She is a widow with a child who is too young to work or study.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old married man with one baby girl. He lives with his family in Lebanon.

He has been running a shoe store for the past five years in his town and is the main income provider for his wife and daughter. He offers women’s and children’s shoes in his store and his shop is well-known by his customers because his prices are lower.

Today, he is requesting $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to expand his store’s inventory and to diversify his merchandise selection. In the future, he is hoping to expand his business and sell men’s shoes as well.

loans.use: to expand his store’s inventory and diversify his merchandise selection

loans.name: Teng

texts.en: Teng C., 22, is married and lives with her husband and child in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. C. and her husband are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of $3.5  USD each per day. The family has to spend $35 USD on food, $5 USD on electricity supply and $30 USD on public transport every month. C. is requesting a loan of $500 USD to purchase cows for resale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy cows for resale

loans.name: Rovshan

texts.ru:
Rovshan B. 48 let. On yavlyayetsya otcom 2 detey. Sin kotoromu 18 let on v etom qodu postupil v universitet i doch 16 let uchitsya v shkole a takje zanimayetsya risovaniyem. Rovshan B. i yeqo semya jivut v Absheron regione. 

Uje 10 let kak Rovshan zanimayestya zemledeliyem. Etomu biznessu on nauchilsya u brata kotoromu v svoye vremya nauchil ix otec. Ranshe Rovshan imel vinoqradniy sadik , no potom on reshil zanatsya zemledeliyem.
Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit neobxodimoye obarudivaniye dlya postroyki parnika.
texts.en:
Rovshan B. is 48 years old. He is the father of two children. His son, who is eighteen, entered the university this year. His sixteen-year-old daughter studies at school and draws. Rovshan B. and his family live in the Absheron region. Rovsham has been working in agriculture for ten years. He started this business with the help of his brother, who, in his own time, started with their father. Rovsham used to have a vineyard, but he later decided to take up farming. Currently, he needs 2000 AZN to buy materials to build a hotbed.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy materials to build a hotbed

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
Teodora B. is from the village of San Lorenzo. She is 47 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Teodora owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs for fattening and sale. Teodora has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,500 PHP when she sells a raised pig.
In 2010, Teodora joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Teodora is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Rahmonali

texts.ru: Курбоналиев Рахмонали проживает в районе Джиликул. Возраст, 28 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Рахмонали имеет высшее образование, юрист. По профессии не работает. Он занимается торговлей горючего, то есть продает солярку, бензин и масло. В этой области более 10 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Rahmonali K. lives in Jilikul. He is 28 years old, married, and has two children. His wife is a housewife. Rahmonali has a law degree, but he does not practice law. He works selling fuel such as diesel, gasoline and oil. He has been doing this work for more than ten years. He is taking out a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Maria Theresa

texts.en:
Maria Theresa L. is from the village of Brgy. Villa Coloma, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 50 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Maria Theresa owns and operates a specialized retail store selling personal products, such as lotions, accessories and watches, in the local community. Maria Theresa has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Maria Theresa joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Theresa is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Seang S., 37, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. S. raises pigs and produces rice wine, earning an income of 6 USD per day. Her husband is a soldier in the province, earning an income of about 4 USD per day. The family has to spend 50 USD on food, 15 USD on public transportation, and 15 USD on their children’s education every month. S. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase pigs and chickens to raise for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. Sokhorn's husband appears in the photograph because S. is not available.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and chickens

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She has been operating her retail shop for five years with the help of her husband. Her customers include neighbours and passersby.

With the 40,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase sacks of beans, maize, rice, and sugar for resale. She sells fresh water as another source of income. Mary cites seasonality as a major challenge in her business. During rainy seasons, the supply is higher than demand; during dry seasons, the demand is higher than supply.

She hopes to open another retail shop in the future. She decided to join Yehu after being introduced by a friend. Mary owns a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To purchase beans, maize, rice, and sugar

loans.name: Mairamhan Tashpolotova's Group

texts.en:
Mairamhan T. is the leader of the group. She is married and has two children. Her son (28 years old) earns money by working as an accountant (his salary is 4000 KGS per month). Her daughter (19 years old) is a dressmaker. Mairamhan’s spouse works in Bishkek. 11 years ago the family started their own cattle-breeding business by purchasing a calf. Since they started the business, they have been able to build a house and arrange their son’s wedding. Mairamhan hopes to get a loan in order to buy a calf for fattening. In the future, the family wants to organize their daughter’s wedding and to increase their cattle stock. 

Hilolahon J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 29 years old and married. Her spouse is an auto mechanic. The couple is raising two children; the older one is in school. With her portion of the loan, she intends to purchase furniture and lace for curtains in order to decorate the house. In the future, the family is planning to save money for their son’s wedding and to purchase a lot on which to build a house. 

Sirojidin D. is 51 years old and married. Together with his wife, who works as a salesperson, he has three children. The oldest one works in Russia, their daughter is married and lives separately, and the youngest son works as a baker. The family's primary source of income is from their own business: they sell foodstuffs by retail trade. Earnings from their business helped to pay for their daughter’s wedding. The purpose of this loan is to purchase more goods in order to increase their inventory. In the future, Sirojidin wants to build a house for his sons. 

Oltinoi J., 36, is divorced. She has two daughters: one is in school and one is not yet attending school. Ten years ago with the initial investment of 5000 KGS Oltinoi started growing cotton and potatoes. With money received from the loan she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase a refrigerator. In the future she wants to provide her daughters with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135  If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf

loans.name: Azizahon's Group

texts.en: Azizahon A., 33, is married and she has the status of being this group’s leader. Her husband earns his livelihood by working as a private builder. The couple is raising two sons: the elder one is a schoolboy and the younger goes to kindergarten. The family has its own business: they earn money by keeping poultry, a business they started after they had moved to their new house. Azizahon hopes to obtain a loan in order to purchase hens for further breeding. In the future, Azizahon wants to build a bath-house, a kitchen, and to install gates. Hilola A., 23, is not married and lives with her parents. She is the treasurer of the group. Her mother works in a school and her father went to Russia in order to earn money. The family has its own business cultivating agricultural products and out of their profits they have managed to install gates. Hilola hopes to obtain a loan in order to purchase cellophane (a thin, transparent sheet made of regenerated cellulose) for her hothouse plants. In the future, she is planning to obtain a dowry, to marry, and to finish building her house. Gairatjon B., 31, is married and has no children. He makes his bread by being a farm member. He and his wife run their own business: keeping poultry and breeding hens. In the course of three years they have managed to increase the number of their poultry. The purpose of this loan is to purchase more hens for breeding. In future Gairatjon is planning to do major house repairs, to build a bath-house and a kitchen, and to install gates. Hakimjon K., 35, is married and is a farmer. He and his wife raise two children, a son and a daughter, both of whom go to school. The family earns money from running their own business: eleven years ago they were excited to receive a cow as a gift and, since then, they have bred cattle. In the course of working hard they have managed to build a stable. The purpose or this loan is to purchase cattle for further fattening and resale. In the future, Hakimjon wants to make major house repairs and build a bath-house. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase more hens

loans.name: Soam

texts.en:
Soam P., 54, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

P. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2.50 per day. One of her daughter raises pigs to sell, earning an income of about USD 3 per day while two other children are employed at a factory, earning an income of about USD 3 each per day to help cover the family expenses. Every month the family has to spend USD 43 on food, USD 2.50 on electricity supply, and USD 15 on their children’s education.

P. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a motorbike for their family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family to use

loans.name: Kem

texts.en:
Kem S., 54, is married and lives with her husband and eight children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples.

S. and her husband grow rice to sell, earning an income of about USD 2.50 each per day. Three of her children are employed at different workplaces, earning an income of about USD 3 each per day to help cover the family expenses. Every month the family has to spend USD 35 on food, USD 10 on electricity supply, and USD 15 on their children’s education.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work

loans.name: Abdukahor

texts.ru: Аманов Абдукахор проживает в районе Джиликул. Возраст, 37 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Образование средне - специальное, продавец. Вместе с женой занимается торговлей. Арендует торговую точку, где продает растительное масло. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 20 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Abdukahor A. lives in Jilikul. He is 37 years old, married, and has five children. He has a vocational education as a salesman. He and his wife sell both at home and in the market. At the market, he rents a shop where he sells vegetable oil. He has been doing this for twenty years. He is taking out a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Rebbeca

texts.en:
Rebbeca T. is currently in the business of baking and selling bread and is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to establish a green vegetables farm.


Rebbeca is 46 years old and is divorced. She has five children and her children go to school.

loans.use: To stock more baking flour

loans.name: Kuy

texts.en:
Kuy N., 30, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. Her husband appears in the photograph because N. was not available.

N. produces traditional baskets to sell for an income of USD 3 per day while her husband sells chickens, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. Every month the family has to spend USD 40 on food, USD 30 on public transportation, and USD 15 on their children’s education.

N. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase pigs and chickens to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy chickens and pigs to sell

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David K. M. is 41 years old and married. His wife is employed as a clerk and they have four children aged between one month and twelve years. They hope to give their children a very good quality education to university level. David's business is located at Mwembe Tayari, where he offers computer repair services to the people around Mombasa town. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the white beaches of the Indian Ocean.
David would love to grow his business to augment his income (he is also employed). He works very hard from early morning to late in the evening and manages his time in order to keep his business going well. He is using his loan of 20,000 KES to buy computer accessories to expand his business and be able to serve a greater number of customers. He hopes to be a prominent businessman in the future. He describes himself as very hardworking, honest and faithful.

loans.use: To purchase computer accessories

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret T.  is currently in the business of owning a restaurant and selling clothes and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell.  Margret is 31 years old and is married. Her husband is a carpenter. She has 6 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop to sell her clothes.

loans.use: Stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Feliciah

texts.en:
Feliciah is a married woman with three children whom all attends school. Her husband is a contractor and he contributes to her other source of income. She has been operating her restaurant business for the last five years. She sells to her neighbours from home.

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase a freezer for her soft drinks sales. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business especially during December holidays, many families visits Mombasa coastal regions over the holidays unlike the other months where customer turn out is very low.

She hopes to operate a big hotel in the future.Her major aim of joining Yehu is to access loans to boost her business. She owns a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer for soft drinks sales.

loans.name: Garnik

texts.en:
Garnik D. is from the village of Arpeni in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He is married with three children; a 28 year old daughter and two sons (24 and 27 years old).  Garnik has a high school education from his home town of Arpeni.  His daughter is married and lives in the city of Gyumri.  Garnik assists his daughter’s family with home grown vegetables and financial support.  Garnik supports his family with cattle and sheep breeding.  He has been in this work for over 30 years.  He considers himself a hard working yet modest person.  

Garnik is looking for a loan to purchase additional sheep and feed.  With the loan he is expecting his family income to increase by 20%.  The region around Arpeni is favorable for cattle breeding and the current market prices for meat are fair.  In addition to assisting his daughter Garnik is saving funds for his sons’ weddings.  He enjoys living near his extended family in his village of Arpeni.

loans.use: To purchase additional sheep and feed

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian U. is currently in the business of selling groundnut, lemons and green vegetables  and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of groundnuts to sell.  Vivian is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 6 children and 3 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest her profits into her business by stocking various goods to sell

loans.use: Stock more bags of groundnuts to sell

loans.name: Fotima

texts.ru: Азимова Фотима жительница города Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 44 год. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Образование среднее. Занимается торговлей на центральном рынке города. Имеет торговую точку, где продает конфеты. В этой области имеет богатый опыт. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en:
Fotima A. is a resident of Qurgan-Tube. She is 44 years old, married, and has one child. She has a high school education. She trades in the central market of the city. She has a shop where she sells candy. She has vast experience in this. She is taking out a loan to increase the variety of goods she sells.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the variety of goods sold

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose D.  is currently in the business of baking bread and selling rice and beans and is requesting a loan to stock more beans and rice to sell.  Rose is 28 years old and is divorced.  She has 3 children and 2 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy goats to raise.

loans.use: Stock more beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Shaving and sterilising machines

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline A.  is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, 'simsim', lemons and greens and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of 'simsim' to sell.  Jackline is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 6 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy goats and chickens to rear at home.

loans.use: Stock more bags of 'simsim' (sesame seeds) to sell

loans.name: Shahen

texts.en:
Shahen G. is from the village of Bavra in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He is the proud father of a 4-year-old daughter and a 2-year-old son. Shahen and his wife have been engaged in raising cattle for the past 15 years.  Shahen also financially supports his brother’s family.  

Shahen is looking for a loan to purchase calves and feed.  According to his business plan, the proceeds from the loan should increase the family income by 20%.  Shahen dreams of saving enough money for his children to attend college and purchasing a tractor for the family business.  He considers himself fortunate to live in the clean environment of Bavra, close to extended family and friends.  Shahen looks forward to continuing his business in the place of his birth.

loans.use: purchasing calves and feed

loans.name: Numa

texts.en: Numa A. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and tomatoes  and is requesting a loan to stock dried fish to sell.  Numa is 32 years old and is married to a husband who is a farmer. She has six children and three of her children go to school.  She hopes to be able to use the extra profits from her loan for agricultural purposes.

loans.use: Stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Burora Traders A, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
With his small savings from his previous farming ventures, N. Patrick of Burora Traders, 37 and the married father of six, was able to start up his coffee trade businesses alongside bananas sales. He goes to farmers directly and makes purchases of raw coffee berries which he dries and takes to factories for resale. 

This earns him a clean profit of 600,000 on a monthly basis. Therefore with this loan he looks forward to collecting more stock for his store and expanding business in the short run. Earning more revenue is Patrick’s main motive because he will be financially stable and better able to take care of his family and also live a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: Buying more coffee for resale

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice A. O. is a married lady with ten children, aged between twenty-nine years old and fourteen years old. Her business is located at the centre of Nyamasaria market along the Kisumu-Nairobi road in Kisumu. She has been operating a food kiosk in which she sells ready-made food to the local residents and travellers. 

She has been doing this business for the last ten years and she says that this business is profitable but the major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy general items like cooking oil and maize flour for making the food that she sells. She hopes to grow her business to an ultra modern restaurant. She describes herself as humble, obedient and motivated.

loans.use: Maize flour, cooking oil, etc

loans.name: Safarmo

texts.ru: Ахмедова Сафармо проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 42 года. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Образование среднее. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Имеет торговую точку, где продает конфеты и шоколад. В этом ей помогает муж. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en:
Safarmo A. lives in Qurgan-Tube. She is 42 years old, married, and has one child. She has a high school education. She has been trading in the market for more than five years. She has a shop where she sells candy and chocolate. Her husband helps her. She is taking out a loan to increase the variety of goods she sells.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing the variety of goods sold

loans.name: Buroratraders  B, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Hard-working N. Ivan of Burora Traders group, aged 33, is a married father of two children. He went into a business venture of carpentry now close to 7 years ago, having got this idea from his friend and this being his trade, he built on it. Being a strategically located business in Burora, Kihihi town in western Uganda, Ivan gets many customers earning him 200,000 Ugandan shillings monthly. 

With this loan, he is looking forward to restock his business with more materials such as timber and also doing more advertising to increase the numbers of customers. This will definitely give his enterprise a new lease on life and also help him improve his sales and be able to take good care of his family as his goal is to have his children educated.

loans.use: restocking his business with more carpentry materials such as timber

loans.name: Vachagan

texts.en:
Vachagan H. lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Aghin.  He is a hardworking farmer with 20 years of experience in cattle breeding and growing vegetables.  

Vachagan is married with three children – an eighteen-year-old daughter and two sons (16 years old and 20 years old).  In addition to supporting his family Vachagan also helps his relatives in the nearby city by sending vegetables from his farm.  His dream, as a father, is to have all his children graduate from university. 

In order to grow his business, Vachagan is looking for loan to purchase seeds and fuel.  According to his plans the investment will increase his family income by around 15%.  He is impressed with the positive attitude and service of microfinance.  Vachagan was born in Aghin and hopes it will be his permanent home.  He is surrounded by a large extended family and enjoys working on the land.

loans.use: seeds and fuel

loans.name: Sansizbai

texts.en:
Sansizbai U. is 51 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Bayan-Ulgiy province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian home/tent. Two of his children attend a local high school and one son operates a taxi business in the local community. His wife is currently unemployed. 

Sansizbai operates a grass and fodder trading business. In addition, Sansizbai works in construction during the summer months. He has been engaged in his grass and fodder trading business for the past 10 years and has built a stable and successful operation. He moves and buys grass in bulk from hay lands in Nogoonnuur sub-province during hay time to resell in the capital city of the province. 

Sansizbai says, " I want to have my own truck to transport my products." He needs more funds to transport his bulk grasses from hay lands to the capital city of the province and therefore he is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan.

loans.use: To transport his hay

loans.name: Ruzanna

texts.en:
Ruzanna lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Marmashen.  She is married and the proud mother of two daughters (twenty-eight years old and twenty-one years old) and a twenty-nine-year-old son.  Ruzanna supports her daughter’s family, who lives in the town of Artik, with agricultural produce. 

 Ruzanna has been engaged in vegetable growing and raising animals for over 18 years.  She considers herself a hard worker and is proud to be a farmer.  Ruzanna would like a loan to purchase additional animals and seeds and feed.  She is expecting the family income to increase by up to 20% with the business investment.  By growing her business she expects to fully support her family and be able to stay in Marmashen.  Ruzanna is fond of her village which has an ancient monastery complex of five churches built in the 10th century.

loans.use: purchase animals, seed and feed

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan H. is from the village of Isahakyan in the Shirak region of Armenia. As she lacks the full financial means to grow her business she is pleased with the opportunity provided by microfinance to finance her business plan.

Susan has been engaged in growing wheat and barley and livestock for over twenty years and considers herself a hardworking and sincere person. In order to support her husband and three children: two daughters, nineteen and twenty-three years, and a twenty-one-year-old son, she is planning to increase the family income to refurbish her cow shed.

Susan is looking for a loan to purchase wheat and barley seeds and feed. She expects the family income to increase by 25% with this investment and, by expanding her business, she will be able to continue living in Isahakyan, which is the place of her birth. Surrounded by her extended family and friends, she enjoys the rural life.

loans.use: To buy wheat and barley seeds and feed

loans.name: Mnatsakan

texts.en:
Mnatsakan K. is from the village of Isahakyan, which is located in the Shirak region of Armenia. He is happily married with three children: two daughters, thirty-three years old and twenty-seven years old, and a thirty-five-year-old son. 

Mnatsakan has a high school education and has been working as a farmer for the past twenty years growing vegetables, fruit and grains. He considers himself a hard worker and enjoys the life on a farm.

Mnatsakan is looking for a loan to expand his farm and to purchase wheat and barley seeds. With this investment he is expecting his family income to increase by 15% and is planning to use some of the proceeds to purchase new machinery to support the family business. He also will support his daughter’s family who live in the capital city, Yerevan.

Mnatsakan was born in Isahakyan and takes pleasure in the rural life, surrounded by his relatives and close friends.

loans.use: To buy wheat and barley seeds

loans.name: Solange

texts.en:
Solange was born in 1980 and is married with two children. She also takes care of one dependent.

Solange is businesswoman but her husband doesn't work. For that reason, she works hard so that she is able to provide all the basic needs of her family.

Solange owns a small business selling various products such as rice, sugar, and so on. She has an experience of four years in her business and she says that her business is profitable in her area. The hours of her business are from five in the morning to nine in the evening every day.

Solange is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing more products for her store. With this loan, she expects to earn more profits to use for her family and in her business as well.

With the extra income, Solange will be able to save money for her future.

loans.use: To purchase more products for her store

loans.name: Gibson

texts.en:
Gibson W. is a 28-year-old gentleman who is married with one child who is five years old.

Gibson runs a butchery in Thika town and he has been doing this for the last two years. He is able to take home a profit of about Kshs 9,400 every month.

Gibson is a new client at KADET and he has applied for his first loan which he will use to buy more cows for slaughter, thus adding more stock to his butcher shop.

Gibson hopes that his business will go well and that, in the future, he will be able to open more branches as well as buy a plot on which he will build rental houses. Thus he will increase his income and improve his family upkeep.

loans.use: To buy more cows for slaughter, thus adding stock to his butcher shop

loans.name: Lutfiya

texts.en: A married mother of two, Lutfiya has worked tirelessly for the past seven years to develop her lump sugar production business in Kurgantyube central market. A resident of one of the impoverished areas of Tajikistan, Lutfiya is determined to provide the best standard of living possible for her family of four. With the spirit of a true entrepreneur, Lutfiya started this business at a young age in her parents’ house. As such, she has been successful in maintaining a stable growth in this novel business. Lutfiya is a woman of character and strength. Her determination and integrity have helped her to develop a strong reputation among her clients and her fellow entrepreneurs. Currently, Lutfiya is seeking a loan for 3,000 USD to purchase stable shelf ingredients for the production of lump sugar. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchasing ingredients for the production of lump sugar

loans.name: Working For Tomorrow. Group

texts.en:
Mama M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Working For Tomorrow.  She is 30 years old and married. She has three children who are between the ages of 1 month and 12 years. She was only able to attend school through 8th grade due to financial constraints. 

For seven years, she has been selling charcoal in the Fiamah Market in Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000-Liberian-Dollars portion of this 30,000-Liberian-Dollars group loan to buy more bags of charcoal.

She describes herself as a hard-working woman whose goals are to improve her business and to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Virginie

texts.en:
Viriginie was born in 1964 and is married with six children; the first one is 22 and the last one is 12 years old. Virginie is a business woman and her husband is a teacher; these parents work hard so that they provide all that is necessary for their children because they have a big family. 

Viriginie rents out the decoration materials; this business is profitable and that is the reason why ti was chosen by her. The business is well-known in her residence place. Viriginie is serious: her business starts at 5 in the morning and is open to 6 in the evening every day.

Virginie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more equipment to be used in her business. This expansion will make her more effective and efficient and successful.

loans.use: Purchasing more equipment to rent out

loans.name: Suhrob

texts.en:
Suhrob is not married and lives with his parents. He uses his car to offer taxi services in his city and between neighboring cities as well. Suhrob has been in this business for 2 years. Using the phone to get client’s orders, he always has plenty of clients. This business is the main source of income for his family. 

Suhrob would like to borrow 1500 USD to fix his car engine and other parts. As he makes more profit, he hopes to improve his family’s living conditions. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for repairing his car

loans.name: Khusen

texts.en:
Khusen is a widower and he has five children. He started his business doing goods transportation with his truck. He has been doing that already for more than three years and earns just enough to live on. So Khusen decided to purchase another gas cylinder and thus save on road expenses. Also, he wants to get some spare parts for his truck. 

Khusen has gained a reputation for responsibility with his financial obligations and for keeping his word. We are happy to have another opportunity to assist him with the operation of his business.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
