Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing gas cylinder for his truck

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia J.  is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste  and is requesting a loan to stock more goods like 'simsim' and maize to sell.  Lucia is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

loans.use: Stock more goods like 'simsim' (sesame seeds) and maize to sell

loans.name: Tsuma

texts.en:
Tsuma is a married man with fifteen children, six of whom currently attend school. His wife is a farmer and she contributes to the family's basic needs. Tsuma lives in a rental house with neither electricity nor piped water and his greatest monthly expense is clothing.

He has been operating his tailoring business for over twenty years. He mends garments as well as making clothing which he sells retail. The major challenge of his business is seasonality. Tsuma's best season is the month of January when the school year begins and there is high demand for school uniforms.
 
He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his tailoring business. With the Kshs 40,000 he wants to purchase fabric, sewing thread and buttons. Tsuma hopes to start up a retail shop in the future.

loans.use: To purchase fabric,  sewing thread  and buttons

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stock more fish to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary J. is currently in the business of selling cereals and owns a little restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant.  Mary is 33 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuffs in her little restaurant

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday J.  is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a little restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs to sell.  Sunday is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a manager. She has not produced any children yet.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business and build a house.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy P. is from the town of Banga. She is 39 years old and married. She has 4 children aged 13, 14, 17 and 19. To make a living, Juvy owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Juvy got involved in farming when she was in her 20s.

Juvy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juvy has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Juvy is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and financially support her immediate and extended families.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Help Together Group

texts.en:
Victoria K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called 'Help Together'.  She is 42 years old, married, and has five children who are between the ages of 10 to 25 years old. She was only able to attend school through 8th grade due to financial constraints. 

For 14 years, she has been selling fish in Fiamah Market in Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 58,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more cartons of fish. 

She describes herself as an honest woman whose goals are to improve her business and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish

loans.name: Hamuduni

texts.en:
Hamuduni is 43 years old and married with five children between 12 and 1 year old. He takes care of one dependent relative who is 15 years old. Hamuduni is a businessman and his wife does not work outside her home. That's the reason why he works with a great deal of effort so that he provides all the basic needs for his big family. 

Hamuduni is experienced enough because he has two years of experience in his business selling various products such as: cooking oil; rice, bread and so on. The hours of his business are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day except Saturday.

Hamuduni is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business through purchasing more products for his store. With this expansion Hamuduni expects to earn more profits to be used in his business and for his family as well.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane Y. is currently in the business of selling dried fish. She is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and more dried fish to sell.  

Jane is 32 years old and is married to a peasant. She has five children and four of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy goats to rear at home.

loans.use: Stock tomatoes and more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel J. is from the town of Banga. He is 45 years old and married. Joel is a farmer. He tills his land to plant and harvest rice crops. He raises chickens also. Joel works hard to provide for his family. He hopes to have a good business and a stable income.

Joel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joel has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Joel is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs and feed. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and feed

loans.name: Bikamwa Plus Group

texts.en:
Serge is the chairman of a Community bank named “Bikamwa Plus”, which is composed of 20 micro-entrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Serge is 28 years old and single. He runs a telephone booth and is a money changer. He started his business in 1996 with a beginning capital of US$ 150. With hard work and determination, his business prospered.  Serge’s business is located in the west of the city of Kinshasa. He has already received  Hope DRCongo’s loans three times and repaid them correctly. He intends with the next loan to purchase more prepaid cards and increase his inventory in order to reinforce his working capital. He makes US$ 65 in profit each week. His ambition is to purchase a generator to rent out and to become a card provider in his area.

loans.use: to purchase more prepaid cards and increase his inventory to reinforce  working capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina H. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Gina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Gina says she works hard because she wants to provide for her family. She wants to provide better living conditions.

Gina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Gina is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more slippers for resale

loans.name: Ditalala Plus Group

texts.en:
Nathalie is the leader of a community bank named “Ditalala Plus”, which is composed of 18 micro-entrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through microfinance institution, HOPE RDC, with the goal of developing their businesses.
Nathalie, 39, is married and has three children aged between seven and ten years old, two of whom attend school. Nathalie sells beans, peanuts and eggs. She started her business in 2009. She has worked with determination and good management in order to achieve her goal of opening a large bean facility in her locality. With her next loan she intends to purchase a sack of peanuts and miscellaneous goods to increase the inventory of her business. Currently, she earns a profit of $77 each week.

loans.use: To purchase a sack of peanuts and miscellaneous goods for resale

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira D., 45, is from the town of Banga. Elvira is married and is the mother of a 27-year-old. To make a living, Elvira owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also raises chicken layers to produce and sell eggs. 

Elvira joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvira has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Elvira is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP that will be used to purchase farm inputs and feeds for the chickens. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and feeds for the chickens

loans.name: Vedaste

texts.en:
Vedaste is 48 years old and married with four children between the ages of 8 and 4 months. He and his wife are in business. Both work with a great deal of effort in order to provide all the necessities for the family. Vedaste owns a brick business. This business is profitable and he has 2 years of experience with it. The hours of his business are from 6 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day.

Vedaste is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business which will allow him to satisfy his customers. Vedaste expects to earn more profits which will be used in his business and in his family as well.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Today Sunshine Group

texts.en:
Deddeh W., who is holding the sign in the picture, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Today Sunshine.  She is 40 years old married, and has five children who are between the ages of three to twenty years. She was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to financial constraints. 

For seven years, she has been selling used clothes and working in the motorcycle transport business in Wroto Town Community Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollars portion of this 46,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bags of used clothes, spare parts and petroleum.
She describes herself as an easy-going woman whose dream is to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes, spare parts and petroleum

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie A. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has three children ages 16, 13 and 8. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Tessie also runs a sari-sari store now. She sells different kinds of products that her neighbors usually look for. Tessie hopes for her ventures to prosper.

Tessie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP that will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: United Sisters Group

texts.en:
Miatta K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called United Sisters.  She is 47 years old, married, and has five children who are between the ages of twelve to twenty-two years. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial constraints. 

For five years, she has been operating a mini-restaurant in Via Town, Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 25,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 63,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of rice, pepper, meat, fish, tomatoes, onions, etc. 

She describes herself as an honest woman whose goals are to improve her business and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: buying rice, pepper, meat, fish, tomatoes, onions, etc.

loans.name: Progrès Plus Group

texts.en:
“Progrès Plus” is a group of 14 owners of small businesses chaired by Rose. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses.

Rose is a seamstress (specifically a dressmaker) and sells clothes in her area. She became a micro-entrepreneur in 1986. Her business is located in the western area of Kinshasa. She has already received five loans from the microfinance institution HOPE DRC and fully repaid them. 

She intends to use this loan to buy fabrics to sew clothes and sell them at profit in order to increase her working capital. Currently she earns a profit of $55 per week. Rose is 34 years old, married and the mother of six children aged between 6 and 14. Four of them attend school. Her dream is to someday open a large sewing workshop in her environment located west of Kinshasa.

loans.use: purchasing fabrics to sew clothes and sell them

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Gracias Morenita Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Gracias Morenita inicia su ciclo 14 con 21 socias.
La señora Julia es por primera vez presidenta D. su Banco Comunal, asume con M. entusiasmo y alegría, lo que mas le agrada D. Finca Perú es el incentivo al ahorro y la facilidad D. los prestamos que le ayudan M. a su negocio.
Julia es casada, tiene 5 hijos y solo 1 esta estudiando. Julia venD. comida especialmente cebiche D. manera ambulatoria al frente D. una institución publica, actividad que realiza desD. las 9 D. la mañana hasta las 12 del mediodía.
Julia necesita un préstamo D. 600 soles para la compra D. aceite, arroz y platos.
Julia tiene una casa D. material rustico y su sueño es construir D. material noble, también le gustaría ampliar su negocio y que su hija sea profesional.
texts.en:
The “Gracias Morenita” communal bank begins its 14th cycle with 21 members. Julia is President of her communal bank for the first time. She takes on the position with enthusiasm and joy. What she likes best about Finca Perú is the savings incentives and the ease of payment terms on the loans that are of great use for her business. Julia is married and has five children only one of whom is in school. She sells food, especially cebiche (marinated fish) in front of a public institution from 9am until noon. Julia needs a 600 sol loan to buy cooking oil, rice and dishes. Julia has a house maD. from rustic materials and her dream is to build with substantial materials. She’d also like to expand her business and that her daughter becomes a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, rice and dishes.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “Madres Trabajadoras”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito D. Santiago, perteneciente a la provincia D. Cusco y departamento D. Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Dolores; ella tiene 57 años D. edad y es casada  y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el  negocio D. venta D. comida en el terminal D. una empresa que hace servicio público llamada Sr D. Cabildo, ella trabaja desD. las 5:00 a.m hasta las 4:00 p.m, su esposo trabaja en el sector salud y juntos sacan adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere tener un restaurant para poder preparar los deliciosos platos que cocina.  La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar  productos para cocinar como arroz, azúcar, carne, fideos y utensilios. 


La socia agradece a quienes forman parte D. este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago D. sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Dolores belongs to the “Madres Trabajadoras” (Working Mothers) communal bank, which is located in Santiago district, Cusco province, in the department of Cusco. Dolores is 57 years old, married, and has 2 children. Her daily activities incluD. a business selling meals in the terminal of an enterprise called "Sr. D. Cabildo" that performs public services. She works from 5:00am until 4:00pm. Her husband works in the health sector and together, they manage to advance their children. Dolores wants to open a restaurant where she can prepare the delicious meals she cooks. Dolores is requesting a loan to buy cooking products, such as rice, sugar, meat, beans, and also cooking utensils. Dolores thanks everyone who by this means becomes part of her dream, and she promises to comply with her payments as scheduled.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING PRODUCTS FOR COOKING, SUCH AS RICE, SUGAR, MEAT, BEANS, AND ALSO EATING UTENSILS

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buying provisions for food stall

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “Madres Trabajadoras”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Santiago, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Francisca; ella tiene 51 años de edad y es casada  y tiene 3 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el  negocio de venta de verduras como tomate, cebolla, zanahorias, vainitas y lechuga, ella vende en el mercado llamado Huancaro desde las 6:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m, su esposo trabaja como chofer, la socia quiere tener un local donde pueda vender las verduras.  La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar toda clase de verduras al por mayor.


La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
A member of the community bank “Mujeres Trabajadores” (Working Mothers); The bank is located in the district of Santiago, in the province of Cusco and the department of Cusco.

The member is Francisca. She is 51 years old, married and has 3 children. She alternates her daily activities with the sale of vegetables such as tomato, onion, carrots, peas and lettuce. She sells at the Huancaro market from 6:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m. Her husband works as a chauffeur. She wants to have a shop where she can sell her vegetables. The member asks for this loan to purchase all types of vegetables in bulk.

The member is grateful to everyone who makes up this dream and promises to complete the payments according to schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase all types of vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For the purchase of cleaning products and ceramic painting supplies

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To add more bags of used shoes

loans.name: Lukundo Group

texts.en:
Flora Kinjami is in her early forties, married, and has 6 children. She has a business selling brooms, potatoes, and onions from Iringa to Moshi which she has been operating since 2005. The business runs between 4am and 10 am and earns Flora quite a low monthly profit.

This will be Flora's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. Flora aims to use this loan to increase her capital, buy more products, say twice a month, and to reduce moving upcountry every week. Flora's dream is to one day open a charcoal shop and sell at wholesale price.

Flora will share this loan with her loan group Lukundo, which totals 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans. 

In the photo, Flora can be seen in the middle front row wearing a purple and red dress.

loans.use: Increase capital in order to buy more products

loans.name: Sala Sambila Plus Group

texts.en:
Mayimona N. is the manager of a community bank called “Sala Sambila Plus”. It is composed of 13 members united in solidarity to receive Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.
Mayimona is a carpenter and owns a sawmill. He has been a micro-entrepreneur since 1992 and has acquired solid experience in woodwork. His business became stable thanks to hard work and accumulated profits that he reinvested. Currently, his business brings in a profit of $180 each week. Last August, Mayimona decided to join one of Hope’s groups named “Sala Sambila Plus” meaning “Work and Pray” in English. His business has been strengthened through the loans. With his next loan, Mayimona plans to buy some sawmill tools in order to meet customer requirements and generate additional profits. He is 49 years old and a father of a son aged 20 who goes to school.

loans.use: To buy some sawmill tools

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Martha Petrona

texts.es: Martha Petrona se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos también se dedica a vender productos lácteos, ella busca la forma de generar ingresos para su hogar. Esta no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos para su negocio. A su cargo esta su hija de 7 años, que con el esfuerzo de ella estudia, ella ha realizado un gran esfuerzo para mantener sus negocios. Pues todos los días se levanta muy temprano para comenzar con su labor. Con este crédito quiere realizar la compra de leche, cuajada, crema y queso es una mujer responsable.
texts.en:
Martha Petrona sells clothing and cosmetics but she also sells dairy products. She is always looking for ways to increase family income. This isn’t her first business loan. She has a 7 year old daughter in her care that is able to go to school thanks to her efforts for she has put in a great effort to keep her businesses running. She rises very early every day to start her tasks. She will use the loan to buy milk, cottage cheese, cream and cheese. She is a responsible woman.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk, cheese, cream and cottage-cheese.

loans.name: Mt. Livingstone Group

texts.en:
Ally N. is in his mid-30s and is married with three children. He owns a tailoring shop, which he has been running for ten years now. His shop is open daily between 7am and 8pm, and earns Ally a good monthly profit.
This will be Ally's first motisha loan with Kiva partner, Tujijenge Tanzania. A motisha loan is a Tujijenge Tanzania product that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. With this loan, Ally aims to increase his stock of material, including cloth, thread and needles. His dream is to one day have people working for him so that he can focus on producing new designs.
Ally will share this loan with his loan group, Mt. Livingstone, which totals five members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loans. In the picture, Ally is the only man.

loans.use: To increase stock of material

loans.name: Cleofe

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “Madres Trabajadoras”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Santiago, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra.Cleofe; ella tiene 38 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el  negocio de venta de ropa para niños y adultos, ella vende en forma ambulatoria y también envía a la ciudadela de Machupicchu para que alla lo venda su hermana que también se dedica al negocio de venta de ropa, su esposo es chofer de servicio de taxi y juntos sacan adelante a su familia, la socia quiere tener una tienda de venta de ropa. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar  mercadería como pantalones, blusas, chompas y polos.


La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Cleofe belongs to the community bank “Madres Trabajadoras.” The bank is located in the district of Santiago, belonging to the province of Cusco in the department of Cusco.

Cleofe is 38 years old, lives with her partner and has 2 children. Cleofe balances her daily activities with her business selling clothing for children and adults. She sells in the street and also sends them to the area of Machupicchu to be sold by her sister who also has a business in clothing sales. Her husband is a taxi driver and together they are moving ahead with their family. Cleofe wants to have a store selling clothes. She wants the loan to buy merchandise such as pants, blouses, jackets and polos.

Cleofe is thankful to those who make up this dream and promises to complete the payments according to schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise such as pants, blouses, jackets and polos.

loans.name: Ushundi Group

texts.en:
Zainabu M. is in her early 40s and is married with two children, aged 20 and 23. She owns a tailoring shop, which she has been running since 2000. Zainabu's shop is open between 10am and 6pm daily, and she makes a good monthly profit.
This will be Zainabu's first loan with Kiva partner, Tujijenge Tanzania. With this loan, Zainabu aims to increase her stock of materials, including cloth, thread and needles. Zainabu's dream is to one day have her own office with people working with her, as well as acquiring more sewing machines.
Zainabu will share her loan with her loan group, Ushundi, which totals 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other responsible for repaying their loans. In the picture, Zainabu can be seen second from left in the last row, wearing black.

loans.use: To increase stock of materials

loans.name: Yolande

texts.fr:
Agée de 45ans, célibataire et mère d’un enfant de 14ans .Elle est dans la vente des chaussures pour enfants en 1993  avec un capital de 18500f.
Par jour elle vend 10000f et 30000f selon les périodes.
Le prêt va lui permettre d’augmenter le stock de sa marchandise en achetant : les baskets, baby boots, pour fillettes, les bottes sandales pour garçons et filles.
Le choix dans la qualité de marchandises, la recherche des articles à la mode, faire des soldes à la fin de chaque période ou  revoir les prix à la baisse  sont ses stratégies de vente.
Elle veut générer beaucoup de bénéfices et devenir importateur car ouvrir une boutique de ventes des chaussures  pour enfants.
Dans son milieu de vie, elle est  considérer comme une femme courageuse parce qu’elle améliore et s’occupe de la scolarité de son enfant.
texts.en:
Ms. Yolande B. M. is 45 years old, unmarried, and has one child, aged 14. She began a business selling children's footwear in 1993, with a working capital of 18,500 F. On a daily basis, she sells between 10,000 F and 30,000 F worth of shoes, depending on the time of year. This loan will allow her to increase her stock of merchandise by buying sneakers, baby boots for girls, and sandals for boys and girls. Her sales strategies involve choosing good quality merchandise, researching the latest fashions, and settling her accounts at the end of each cycle or reviewing her price reductions. She wants to generate large profits and become an importer in order to open a shop selling children's shoes. Being middle aged, she is considered a courageous woman for improving herself and taking care of her child's education.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy children's shoes such as baby boots, sandals, and sneakers.

loans.name: Cleofe

texts.en:
Cleofe E. is from the town of Banga. She is 39 years old and married. To make a living, Cleofe owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Cleofe works hard because she wants her farm to be productive.
Cleofe joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Cleofe is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Mariana De Jesus

texts.es:
Mariana de 37 años, es comerciante informal de ropa, vive con sus hijos de 16 y 14 años en una zona periurbana llamada Perimetral rodeada del estero salado de Guayaquil. 

Hace 6 años atrás su esposo solventaba la economía de su casa mientas que ella estudiaba y atendía a sus hijos, pero el falleció y ella tubo que hacerse cargo de los gastos de su familia vendiendo ropa. Desde ese tiempo hasta ahora vendiendo ropa como comerciante informal para poder mantener a sus hijos. las blusas las vende a $ 20.00, pantalones a $ 30.00 etc. 

Para seguir con su negocio de ropa ella quiere comprar con el préstamo ropa y otra parte dedicarla para mejorar su casa comprando cemento, bloques y pinturas.
texts.en:
Mariana, 37 years old, is an informal clothing merchant who lives with her children, ages 16 and 14, in an area called Perimetral, surrounded by Guayaquil's salt marsh. Some 6 years ago, her husband covered household expenses while she studied and cared for their children. But he died and she had to take charge of family costs by selling clothes. From that time until today, she has sold clothes as an informal merchant to be able to maintain her children. She sells blouses for $20, pants for $30, etc. To continue with her clothing business, she wishes, with this loan, to buy clothes to sell, and also, to buy materials to improve her house, including cement, blocks, and paint.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING CEMENT AND PAINT FOR HER HOUSE AND CLOTHING TO SELL

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga P. is a married woman who lives in Sitio To-ong, Sam-ang, Toledo City, Cebu. She earns a living by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and banana vending business. Her husband, Zosimo P., who is 55 years old, works as a farmer and Brgy. Official to earn a living, and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have four children who are 27 to 33 years old, and all the children have their own families. 

Dominga joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Dominga has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 13,000, which she intends to use to buy new stock of merchandise to sell in her general store so that she can continue to save up for future support of her grandchildren to finish their studies. Dominga P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase new merchandise to sell

loans.name: Jacquiline

texts.en:
Jacquiline C. is a 29-year-old married woman, who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and food vending business. She lives in Sitio To-ong, Sam-ang, Toledo City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007, and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari-sari (general) store and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP 4,000. 

Jacquiline is now borrowing PHP 13,000, so that she can purchase more merchandise to sell. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of  PHP 11,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Jacquiline aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Restock her general store with new merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph K. is 23 years old. He is married to an experienced trader with two children, ages 8 and 6 years. Joseph started a business in 2005, selling cigarettes, sweets and batteries. His business is located in Cotton Tree Market in Makeni. Joseph started this business to be able to generate enough profit to provide a livelihood for his family. Joseph works seven days a week and 11 hours daily. On the average, Joseph earns 2,494,000 SLL monthly from his business.

Joseph has a very good loan repayment history. He needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to help him buy cartons of cigarettes and batteries in large quantities. He intends to use the proceeds from this loan to educate his children and provide other support for them. He thanks you for supporting him.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of cigarettes and batteries for resale

loans.name: Nabil

texts.en:
Nabil, 35, is married and the father of four children. He lives in Bint Jbeil, and has owned a marble and granite factory since 2000. He has 17 years of experience in this field, and he knows what to do to expand his business in the perfect way. 

Nabil has been an Al Majmoua client since 2008, with an active loan history in good standing. His previous loan was for improving the business. This time, he's requesting a loan in order to buy necessary tools and merchandise, in addition to increasing his capital. His only aim is to provide a good living for his beautiful family, as well as to expand his business even more in the future.

loans.use: To buy necessary tools and to increase his capital

loans.name: Virgilia

texts.en:
Virgilia V. is a single woman who lives in Brgy. Dakit, Bogo, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: dried fish sales and food vending businesses. Virgilia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Virgilia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her increase her monthly profit to PHP 6,000, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to purchase more dried fish to sell so that she can continue to save up for her future security. 

Virgilia aims to build a new house and buy a motorcycle when she has enough savings. Virgilia V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for resale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Indiana Del Carmen

texts.es:
Indiana es una mujer trabajadora, de 42 años de edad, madre de 3 hijos, hoy en día trabaja como domestica.  Para ayudar  a sus hijos. Ya que es madre soltera, dos de sus hijos trabajan en ventas en el mercado a su misma patrona.
Siendo sus hijos un gran apoyo el cual han logrado hacer su pequeña casa. Trabajando para un futuro mejor.
Lo que desean es la construcción de un cuarto ya que en uno duermen todos, lo que será de privacidad y de comodidad para la familia.
Compraran materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro, zinc, perlines, para comenzar  a construir. Todo está siendo posible a través del financiamiento siendo una puerta a la prosperidad.
texts.en:
Indiana is a working woman, 42 years old, mother of 3 children. Today, she works at home to support her children. She is a single mother. Two of her children work in sales at the market under the same boss.

She knows that her children are a good support having helped her complete her small home. They are working for a better future.

What they want is to construct a new room since they now sleep all together. This would provide privacy and comfort for the family.

They will purchase materials for construction such as rock, sand, cement, iron, zinc, and tiles, to begin construction. Everything is possible thanks to this financing, opening a door to prosperity.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home improvements

loans.name: Noëlly Natacha

texts.fr:
Femme célibataire âgée de 34ans mère de 3enfants dont l’âge varie de 15 à 3ans.
Depuis 18ans, elle vend de la layette au marché.

Son étalage et ses articles pour les enfants attirent les futures mamans et parents.
Par jour, elle vend  15000f minimum et 50000f maximum.
Le prêt va lui permettre de renouveler son stock de marchandises pour vendre plus en achetant : 10douzaine de couches, 10 ensembles tricots, 10ensembles « petits bateaux », 
5 douzaines de paires de chaussons, 20robes fillettes, 10bermudas, 5lots  de tee-shirts  et 
Chaussettes mixtes.

Elle voudrait un jour  avoir 2 ou 3 autres étalage et devenir femme d’affaire dans ce domaine.
Avec les revenus  qu’elle va générée, elle va s’occupée de la scolarité des ses 3 enfants et vivre dans des bonnes conditions.
Elle prise comme exemple dans  son quartier
texts.en:
Ms. Noëlly Natacha L. is 34 years old, unmarried, and has three children whose ages range from 3 to 15 years. For 18 years, she has sold babies' outfits at the market. Her display of children's items attracts future mothers and parents. Each day, she sells between 15,000 F and 50,000 F worth of items. This loan will allow her to replenish her stock of merchandise for sale, and will be used to buy 10 dozen diapers, 10 knitted outfits, 10 petit bateaux" (little boat) outfits, 5 dozen pairs of shoes, 20 girls' dresses, 10 bermuda shorts, 5 batches of t-shirts, and assorted socks. One day, she would like to have two or three additional display stands, and to become a businesswoman in this field. With the income she will generate, she will take care of educating her 3 children and ensuring a good standard of living. She is considered a role model in her locality.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy diapers, knitted outfits, baby bottles, dresses for little girls, etc.

loans.name: Nicasia

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “Madres Trabajadoras”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito D. Santiago, perteneciente a la provincia D. Cusco y departamento D. Cusco.

La socia es la Sra.Nicasia; ella tiene 61 años D. edad y es casada y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el  negocio D. venta D. golosinas en forma ambulatoria, ella venD. en la puerta del colegio Sivirichi  desD. las 10:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m, ella venD. variedad D. golosinas como galletas, dulces, chicles y chupetes, la socia quiere tener un puesto para vender las golosinas. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar  golosinas al por mayor.


La socia agradece a quienes forman parte D. este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago D. sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The member is Mrs. Nicasia. She is 61, married, and has 2 children. The member alternates her daily activities with selling sweets as a street merchant. She sells them in the entrance to the Sivirichi school from 10 am to 6 pm. She sells a variety of sweets such as cookies, candies, gum and lollipops. Nicasia would like to have a stand where she can sell the sweets, and she is asking for the loan to buy them wholesale. Nicasia thanks those who are part of her dream and commits to making her payments in the established time period.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The member is asking for a loan to buy sweets wholesale

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva P. is a married woman who lives in Fisheries, Brgy. Caradio-an, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: pig fattening and fishing businesses. Her husband, Jim, who is 60 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living , and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have five children who are between 30 and 36 years old. 

Eva joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Eva has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 29,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 5,500 PHP, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 16th cycle loan, she is borrowing 29,500 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital for her livestock business and for maintenance on her husband's fishing boat so that her family can continue to save up for future home repairs. 

Eva P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional capital to help fund her business operations

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es: La señora Teresa tiene 57 años, su actividad es una pulpería. Esta no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos, pues son importantes para su negocio. Ella es una mujer muy alegre y dinámica, se siente muy contenta por tener más experiencia con su actividad. Inicio hace más de 16 años con esta actividad por lo que con mucho sacrificio ha logrado mejorar cada día. Es por eso que solicita este crédito para la compra de golosinas, refrescos, pan, jugos lácteos entre otras cosas.
texts.en:
Señora Teresa is 57 years old and runs a small general store. This isn’t the first time that she’s had a loan as they are important for her business. Teresa is a lively and dynamic woman who is happy to have had a lot of experience running her store. She began more than sixteen years ago and by making a great deal of effort, she has gradually managed to improve it. She is now asking for a loan to buy candies, soft drinks, bread, juices and milk products etc.

Translated from Spanish by Jane A, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Sarly

texts.en:
Sarly is a 44-year-old single mother of two who lives with her children in San Rafael Abajo, located in the central valley of Costa Rica. Sarly runs a hair salon where she offers services such as styling, dying, cutting, curling, etc. She also sells hair products including items for the treatment of unhealthy hair. She hopes to use this loan to finance the purchase of various hair products, both for sale and to use while carrying out salon services. 

Sarly wakes up early and walks one hour to work from home. When she arrives, she attends to her clients with appointments first. In a good month, she serves between three and five clients.

Sarly´s long term goal is to remodel her salon. By increasing the physical size of her business, she hopes to attract more clients and to hire some help. Her main obstacle is the high level of competition which exists in the area for the services Sarly offers. Additionally, robberies are not uncommon.

loans.use: For the purchase of hair products

loans.name: Ma.juditha

texts.en:
Ma. Juditha A. is a 39-year old married woman with four children who lives in Brgy. Punao San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. Ma. Juditha has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for two years now and earns a living by selling fish in her community and surrounding areas.		
	
She is purchasing a solar lantern with a PHP 3,100 loan from NWTF to extend her productive hours and at the same time cut fuel costs and save money in the long run.		

About NWTF’s Green Loan Products: Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation believes that the key to poverty alleviation for the poorest is to provide services beyond just credit. To that end, NWTF offers green energy products designed to save money for its clients. In a partnership with SunTransfer and Arc Finance, NWTF distributes solar-powered lanterns that also functions as a charging station for mobile phones. These families normally use kerosene lamps to light their homes. The solar lantern offers a free, environment-friendly renewable source of energy, that allows them to reduce their monthly fuel costs.   

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase solar lantern to extend her productive hours and cut fuel costs

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
María Elena es una mujer dedicada al trabajo, a su familia. Hoy en día trabaja como operaria en un restaurante de Rostí Pollo en diferentes horarios por ser ricos, se venden muchos y los trabajadores trabajamos en turnos diferentes.
Lleva cinco años laborando para apoyar a sus dos hijos, siendo estudiantes aun ya que su esposo labora como guarda de seguridad, y no se alcanza solo con su trabajo. 
Atreves de Afodenic ha logrado hacer mejoras a su casa, siendo ya doce créditos ya que es el medio para lograr las mejoras ya que todo está ah altos costos. Contenta porque ha logrado el objetivo como madre.
Con este préstamo comprara materiales de construcción para hacer un muro en parte de atrás, logrando así tener mejores cuidados en su hogar. Comprara: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro y otros para hacer la obra.
texts.en:
María Elena is a woman who is dedicated to her work and her family. She currently works as a cook at the Rostí Pollo restaurant. Since this business generates plenty of sales, the employees must work different shifts. María Elena has been working five years to support her two children who are in school. Her husband works as a security guard, so she is not alone in supporting their family.

With assistance from AFODENIC, María Elena has been able to make improvements to her house. She has already taken twelve loans to help offset the high cost of these improvements. María Elena is pleased to have accomplished her goals as a mother. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy construction materials for building a wall at the back that will provide better security for her home. She plans to buy stone, sand, cement, iron, and other supplies needed to complete the work.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials for building a wall

loans.name: Hayde Rose

texts.en:
Hayde Rose B. is a married woman who lives in  Brgy. Manghanoy, La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: rice farming, food vending (bananaque) and livestock businesses. Her husband, Fidel, who is 45 years old, works as a farm laborer to earn his living, and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 15 and 17 years old. 

Hayde Rose joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 21 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Hayde Rose has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 29,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of  7,800 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 22nd cycle loan, she is borrowing 29,500 PHP, which she intends to use to maintain her rice field and buy stock for her food vending business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and the expansion of her business. Hayde Rose B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To maintain her rice field and buy stock for her food vending business

loans.name: Santiago Rafael

texts.es:
Santiago de 27 años, vive en una zona periurbana llamada Perimetral rodeada del estero salado de Guayaquil. El y su esposa tienen una pequeña tienda. 

Creo un negocio familiar con algunos ahorros y con la motivación de mantener a sus tres hijos de 5, 3 y 1 año de edad. Su esposa le ayuda en el negocio mientras que el sale a comprar los víveres para la tienda, trabajan desde las 06h00am hasta las 22h00pm todos los días. Venden todo tipo de víveres incluso verduras, legumbres y frutas.  

Para seguir surtiendo su tienda el quiere comprar con el préstamo arroz, bebidas, carnes etc. En el futuro quiere crear una granja de pollos para tener mas ingresos.
texts.en:
27-year old Santiago lives in a suburban area surrounded by a salt marsh along the Perimetral highway in Guayaquil. He and his wife run a small store there. He started the family business with some of his savings in order to earn money to support his three children aged 5, 3, and 1. His wife helps him in the store while he goes off to buy stock to sell in the store. They work from 6 am to 10 pm every day selling all types of products such as vegetables, pulses, and fruit. Santiago wishes to use the loan to buy more stock such as rice, drinks, meat etc. In the future he would like to start up a poultry farm so he can earn more money.

Translated from Spanish by Jane A, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy rice, drinks etc

loans.name: Emilio

texts.en:
Emilio E. is from the town of Banga. He is 59 years old. Emilio is married and has a 30-year-old child. To make a living, Emilio owns and operates a business venture growing crops, specifically, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Emilio also owns a sari-sari (general) store that his wife manages. A variety of different products are sold in their store.

Emilio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilio has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Emilio is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies and additional store merchandise. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business and support his family financially.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and additional store merchandise

loans.name: Hayde

texts.en:
Hayde U. is a widow  who lives in Prk. 7, Brgy. Cabacungan, La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and sugarcane farming. Hayde joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1996, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Hayde has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her increase her monthly profit to PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her eighth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use buy more merchandise for her general store and fertilizer for her sugarcane fields, so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Hayde U. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida B. is a 51-year old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: operating a general store, raising pigs and growing corn. She lives in Prk. 7, Brgy. Cabacungan, La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006, and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her various businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 7,000 PHP. 

Aida is borrowing 25,000 PHP so that she can buy new merchandise to sell at her general store and to fund the operations of her other businesses.   This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Aida aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase new merchandise to sell and fund business operations

loans.name: Marcelle Blanche

texts.fr:
Marcelle Blanche N. est une femme de 43ans célibataire et mère de deux enfants dont l’âge varie entre 14 et 22 . Elle débute son commerce de vente d’habit au marché avec un capital de 30000frs  en 1999, quand elle arrete ses etudes en  classe de 3e par manque de soutien.
Ses ventes  journalieres sont de 45000frs à 80000frs et a une forte clientele parcequ'elle vend des habits de marque et des sous vetements de qualite.
Avec ce prêt elle aimera acheter des robes pour enfants  et des sous-vêtements pour homme, femme et enfants pour renforcer son stock et satisfaire aux gouts varies de sa clientele.
Sa stratégie de vente est de réserver un bon accueil à ses clients et avoir un bon étalage qui attirrent les yeux et avoir des prix abordables.
Son ambition c’est d’être parmi la plus grande commerçante du marché specialisee en habits pour enfants et sous vetements de grande qualite. Pour ses enfants elle aimera qu’ils puissent avoir une bonne scolarisation les soutenir jusqu'a poursuivre des etudes universitaires.
Dans son quartier elle est encouragée pour ce qu’elle fait et a un bon temognage .
texts.en:
Marcelle Blanche N. is a 43 year-old woman, single and a mother of two children aged 22 and 14. She started her business selling clothes on the market with a capital of FRS300,000, after she left school in 9th grade due to a lack of support. Her daily sales vary between FRS45,000 and FRS80,000 and she has a solid client base because she sells brand name clothes and quality underwear. With this loan, she would like to purchase children's dresses, and underwear for men, women and children to rebuild her stock and cater to her clients' varying tastes. Her sales strategy is to give her customers a friendly welcome and to have a pleasant merchandise display that grabs the eye, and affordable prices. Her ambition is to become one of the main sellers on the market for children's clothes and high-quality underwear. She would like to make a good education possible for her children and support them all the way through university. In her neighborhood, she's encouraged in her endeavors and well-liked.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of underwear and children's dresses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase winter clothing

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen S. is a married woman who lives in Prk. 7, Brgy. Cabacungan, La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, pig fattening and rice thresher businesses. Her husband, Diego, who is 56 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have four children between the ages of 20 and 34 years old. 

Helen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Helen has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use to buy stocks of merchandise for her general store, and also to buy feed for her pigs so that she can continue to save up for the education of her youngest child and save so that she can expand her business. Helen S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Edith

texts.fr:
Femme célibataire de 42ans, mère de 3 enfant dont varie entre 12 et 4ans.
En 1996, elle se lance dans la restauration pour se prendre en charge.

Par jour elle vend 50000f   et ses bénéfices sont de 8000f, elle faits des plats promotionnels pour attirer ces clients qui sont les passants, les étudiants et habitants de son quartier.
Avec le prêt actuel, elle va renforcer son commerce en faisant beaucoup de réserve tel que 1sacde riz, 1bidon de 25litres d’huile, 1filet d’oignon, 1carton de tomates, du poisson fumé, du poisson salé, 10litres d’huile de palme, de l’haricot blanc et les arachides.

Dans le souci d’élargir son activité, elle voudra ouvrir un restaurant plus moderne et faire plus de bénéfices afin d’améliorer ses conditions de vie et celui de ses enfants en soutenant leurs scolarités.
texts.en:
This 42-year-old single woman is the mother of three children whose ages range between 4 and 12 years old. She started working in the restaurant business in 1996 as a means of financial support. Her daily sales reach 50,000 francs with profits of 8,000 francs. She prepares promotional dishes to attract her customers who consist of people walking by, students and local residents. With this loan, she plans to bolster her activity by increasing her stocks with one sack of rice, one 25-liter can of oil, one bag of onions, one carton of tomatoes, smoked fish, salted fish, ten liters of palm oil, white beans and peanuts. She wants to expand her business with a modernized restaurant and boost her profits to improve her family’s living conditions and pay for her children’s tuition.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, a can of oil, salted fish, onions, smoked fish, etc.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn T. is from the town of Banga. She is 43 years old. Jocelyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 17 years.

Jocelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm supplies, such as seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies, such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more sugar, milk, soap, coffee, sardines, body cream etc., for resale

loans.name: Crisanta

texts.en:
Crisanta J. is a widow  who lives in Lower Caticugan, Brgy. Caticugan, Siaton, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a food vending  business. Crisanta joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Crisanta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 17th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to pay for more inventory for the business so that she can continue to save up for the future and improve her family's living conditions. Crisanta J. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.es:
La Señora Wilma está casada con el señor Julián  tienen 3 hijos de los cuales 1 de ellos es mayor de edad independiente de ellos, los 2 restantes son menores aún están en  el nivel primario educativo. 
Wilma tiene una despensa bien surtida y es la única del barrio, su negocio está bien surtida y con buenísima clientela ya que es la única despensa que se encuentra en su comunidad.
 Julián es asalariado trabaja como guardia de seguridad de un empresa privada para que con sus ingresos pueda ayudar con los gastos del hogar
Ella es una persona muy trabajadora y dedicada a sus hijos. 
Wilma agradece a la fundación por darle la oportunidad de acceder a un crédito, que gracias a eso pudo aumentar su negocio mediante la compra de azúcar, arroz, fideos, y otras mercaderías.
texts.en:
Señora Wilma is married to Señor Julián. They have three children; the eldest is grown up and has left home, while the two younger ones are still in primary school. Wilma runs a store, the only one in the neighbourhood. It is well-stocked and she has a very good customer base as they have nowhere else to do their shopping. Julián earns his living as a security guard for a private company. His wages help with household expenses. Wilma is a very hardworking person and devoted to her children. She is grateful to the Fundación for the opportunity to obtain a loan which she is using to buy sugar, rice, pasta and other items to better stock the store.

Translated from Spanish by Jane A, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise such as sugar, rice, pasta etc.

loans.name: Gaby

texts.es: Gaby, es una joven madre de familia, con todas las ganas de salir adelante, vive en su casa propia, en compañía de su esposo y sus 2 hijos. El negocio al que Gaby se dedica, es la venta de comida rápida, siendo papas y pollos fritos, platillo de mucha demanda en horas de la tarde. Su punto de venta, es en la puerta de su casa, donde va instalándose  a partir de las 6:00 de la tarde limpiando correctamente su establecimiento, para que pueda sus clientes sentirse cómodos mientras consumen estos platillos. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo; es que puede ser independiente, por otro lado le da mucha satisfacción saber que sus ventas se duplican durante los fines de semana. Han transcurrido 3 años y considera que lo más difícil, es tener que trabajar en invierno; ya que se expone en la intemperie y eso perjudica su salud. Para en el futuro, planea diversificar su negocio, en la venta de ropa y construir su casa. Ingresa a su primer crédito con MFP, por lo que se ha comprometido en pagar puntualmente sus cuotas, puesto que desea tener nuevos créditos y así mejorar su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará cervezas y gaseosas, ya que los fines de semana la gente de su barrio consumen mucho estas bebidas.
texts.en:
Gaby is a young mother who has the desire to succeed. She lives in her own home with her husband and two children. Gaby has a business selling fast foods, such as French fries and fried chicken, which are in great demand during the afternoon hours. Her vending post is set up on the doorstep of her house. She begins cleaning around 6pm so that her customers will be comfortable while eating their food. What she enjoys most about her work is the ability to be independent. In addition, she gets great satisfaction from knowing that she can double her sales on the weekends. Gaby has been in business for three years and considers the most difficult part to be working during the winter because she puts her health at risk by being out in the elements. In the future, she plans to build a house and diversify her business by selling clothing.

Gaby is requesting her first loan from MFP and promises to complete her payments on time. She wants to be eligible for subsequent loans so that she can continue improving her business. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy beer and sodas since her customers consume more of these beverages on the weekends.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sodas & beer

loans.name: Dina

texts.es:
Dina pertenece al Banco Comunal Yanapanakusun que significa Ayudémonos en Quechua.
Dina es soltera y tiene 4 hijos que estudian, Dina vende golosinas variadas en el parque central de la ciudad de Huamanga y también viaja a las fiestas patronales de los diferentes pueblos en donde vende sus productos.
Dina solicita un préstamo de 3000 soles para la compra de galletas y chocolates.
Dina sueña con cambiar su negocio por la venta de ropa.
texts.en:
Dina is a member of the community bank Yanapanakusun, meaning Let's Help One Another in Quechua. Diana is a single mother of 4 children, all are attending school. Dina sells various snacks in the central park of the city of Huamanga, though she also travels to various villages during national feast days to sell her products. Dina requests a loan in the amount of 3000 soles to purchase cookies and chocolates. Dina dreams of changing her business to one where she would sell clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cookies and chocolates.

loans.name: Benita

texts.es:
Benita es socia del Banco Comunal Yanapanakusun que significa Ayudémonos en Quechua.
Benita es soltera y tiene 4 hijos que estudian, Benita tiene un restaurante llamado Katia en un local alquilado, Benita inicio su negocio vendiendo de manera ambulatoria y hace 2 años tiene un local, además vende bebidas, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de 1 persona y también sus hijos en sus tiempos libres.
Benita solicita un préstamo de 1000 soles para la compra de arroz y azúcar.
Los sueños de Benita son tener otro restaurante e implementar un bar.
texts.en:
Benita is a member of the Yanapanakusun communal bank. In Quechua, Yanapanakusun means “Let’s help each other.”

Benita is single and has 4 children who are students. She has a restaurant named Katia in a rented space. She began her business by selling on foot and she has had the restaurant for 2 years. She also sells drinks every day, which she does with the help of another person as well as her children when they are free.

Benita is requesting a 1000 PEN loan for the purchase of rice and sugar. Benita’s dreams are to have another restaurant and to set up a bar.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice and sugar

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda M. is married and lives in Brgy. 8, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: Used Clothing and Ready-To-Wear (RTW) businesses. 

Imelda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Imelda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 27,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use to buy more inventory for her business so that she can continue to save up for future house repairs and be able to sustain her business with her own revolving capital. Imelda M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her business

texts.en: Mamón Group is made up of three hardworking women who put effort into their work.  One of these women is Filena del Rosario

They have six children who are between the ages of 13 and 31 years old. 

Lourdes joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002, because she aspired for something better for her family. Lourdes C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Fredy

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “Madres Trabajadoras”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Santiago, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

El socio es el Sr.Fredy; el tiene 23  años de edad y es soltero, el socio trabaja manejando un carro, el hace servicio de taxi, el tiene un carro propio que trabaja desde las 6:00 a.m hasta las 10:00 p.m, el socio quiere ahorrar para estudiar y también le gustaría mejorar el servicio de Taxi.El socio solicita el préstamo para  comprar accesorios y llantas para hacer arreglar el carro.

	
El socio agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Fredy is a member of the Communal Bank “Madres Trabajadoras” (Working Mothers), which is located in the District of Santiago, Province and Department of Cusco.

He is 23 years old and single. Sr. Fredy drives a car to provide taxi services. He has his own vehicle and works from 6am to 10pm. Fredy wants to save so that he can study, but he also wants to improve his taxi business. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy accessories and tires needed to repair his vehicle.

Fredy is grateful to those who made his dream come true and promises to complete his payments by the established deadlines.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tires & accessories to repair his vehicle

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy G. is married and lives in Sitio Canonoy, Brgy. Miranda, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  a general store and a cafeteria. Her husband, Cirilo G., who is 46 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living, and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have four children between the ages of 11 and 16 years old. 

Juvy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Juvy  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,800, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to pay for more merchandise for her sari-sari (general) store business, so that she can continue to save up for future house repairs and the education of her children. Juvy G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Lucie Yvette

texts.fr:
Femme célibataire de 41ans et mère de 3 enfants dont l’âge varie de 4ans à 15ans. Elle est dans la vente des poissons de mer depuis 2001 et à débuter son commerce avec un capital de 150000frs. Par jour elle vend 120000 à 210000.

Avec le prêt actuel, elle va renforcer son commerce en faisant beaucoup de réserve tel que carton de 2 carton de poisson girel,1 carton sole, 1 carton de bar, 1 carton de barbillon


Elle voudrait un jour  avoir 2 ou 3 autres étalage et devenir femme d’affaire dans ce domaine.
Avec les revenus  qu’elle va générée, elle va s’occupée de la scolarité des ses 3 enfants et vivre dans des bonnes conditions.
Elle est prise comme exemple dans  son quartier
texts.en:
Lucie Yvette T. is 41 years old, unmarried and the mother of three children whose ages range from 4 to 15 years. She has been selling sea fish since 2001 and began her business with a capital sum of 150,000 francs. She sells her fish for 120,000 to 210,000 francs per day.
